executive_summary: The after-school program industry has faced significant challenges due to changing lifestyles and economic headwinds. The rise of remote work has allowed many parents to care for their children after school, reducing the need for external care. Inflation has also reduced disposable incomes, forcing families to cut non-essential expenses like after-school programs. Despite declining unemployment rates, an expected uptick in unemployment by 2024 will further decrease demand as jobless parents can care for their children themselves. However, federal support for after-school programs has helped slow the industry's decline. Revenue has been dropping at a CAGR of 3.3% to an estimated $20.9 billion through 2024, including an expected 1.3% dip in 2024 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Changing Lifestyles and Struggling Wallets Are Driving After-School Program Providers' Revenue Down
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The rise of remote work has given many parents the ability to care for their children after school, reducing demand for after-school programs. Widespread inflation has also cut disposable income, forcing parents to rely on extended family or friends for childcare to save money. As a result, after-school program providers have seen a significant decline in demand and revenue.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: After-school program providers are expected to see some relief moving forward.
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Disposable incomes are set to climb as inflation subsides, allowing parents to afford additional childcare services. An increase in high-earning households will support demand from after-school program providers' top market. However, rising unemployment and continued remote work are expected to keep demand subdued. Providers will need to remain competitive by offering better services and potentially lower fees, muting growth further.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Students are Performing Worse at School
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The shift to online learning during the pandemic led to concerns that students were falling behind. The National Assessment of Educational Progress found that students across all demographics scored lower in 2022 than in 2018. Nearly three-quarters of after-school programs offer educational assistance, and parents have become more willing to pay for this as it's more affordable than private tutors, especially for lower-income families.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Expanding Budgets Will Enable Parents to Offload Childcare
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As inflation subsides, per capita disposable income is set to trend upward, allowing parents to afford after-school care. The number of high-earning households, a key demographic for after-school programs, will also continue to grow, offsetting previous declines.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Rising Unemployment Will Temper Growth and Force Some Providers to Close
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Rising unemployment due to economic turbulence will give more parents time to watch their children after school, reducing demand for after-school programs. Sluggish demand will intensify competition, forcing unsuccessful providers to close and leading to increased industry concentration.

industry_definition: This industry organizes youth programs that take place outside of the traditional school day. After-school programs can occur at various times of the day and in a variety of places, including school buildings, community centers, libraries or parks. Activities include everything from sports and study help to arts and crafts.
key_trends: Location is key. Competition is low in many markets since parents simply send their children to whichever after-school program is located in or nearest to their child's school.

Low pricing helps preserve demand. After-school program providers are consumer-facing, so they're sensitive to changes in consumer spending and disposable income. After-school programs need to offer competitive rates to avoid forcing parents to rely on friends, family or neighbors.
Declining participation has led to revenue losses. Stifled demand stemming from work-from-home flexibility and inflation-strained budgets forced many after-school programs to close permanently.
Growing unemployment and dampened demand will limit recovery.
Despite a gloomy outlook, rising per capita disposable income and strong federal funding will allow after-school programs to achieve some revenue growth.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Higher-Income Households Prioritize Personal Care. Solid growth in the number of households earning over $100,000 per year has lifted this segment's share of revenue. Higher-earning adults often have more obligations and responsibilities at work, leaving them less able to step away and pick up their kids from school. Households earning substantially hire caretakers more often than lower-earning families. Personal sitters are more expensive than after-school programs but provide personalized care for children until parents finished with work.

Low-Income Households Have Differing Priorities. Households with lower incomes often choose nonprofit after-school organizations or subsidized after-school care when available. If not, these families often rely on extended family, friends or neighbors to pick up their kids from school when buses aren't available to drop them off at home. According to the Afterschool Alliance's newest America After 3PM report, low-income families disproportionately value snacks, opportunities to build life skills and academic assistance as more important for an after-school program to offer.

tier_1_suppliers: Hobby & Toy Stores in the US
Copier & Office Equipment Wholesaling in the US
Frozen Food Wholesaling in the US
Egg & Poultry Wholesaling in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The unemployment rate measures the proportion of Americans older than 16 who are unemployed and looking for work. Children who attend after-school programs are more likely to come from a household where both parents work, and parents are more likely to circumvent after-school programs and pick up their children from school themselves when unemployment is high.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast hosts more than a quarter of the nation's population, so there are plenty of K-12 students in the region that rely on after-school care.

While population is by far the primary determinant of the industry's dispersion, some areas have a strong financial industry presence. Metropolitan areas in New York and Pennsylvania often host major headquarters for nationwide corporations, which often require parents to stay in-office when their children are finished with school. This has led to heightened demand for after-school programs in the region, though many top earners instead hire caretakers to pick up their kids and care for them until their parents are done with work.
California, the most populous state, is also the most popular state for after-school programs. High-earning parents in the Golden State provide solid demand for the industry's services.
Regions like the Great Lakes have a disproportionately high number of after-school programs, while regions like the Southeast have more programs than their population would suggest.
Because the industry caters to consumers, after-school program providers are located in close accordance with population trends.
Concentrated demand in urban areas enables after-school program providers to serve a higher number of children per establishment, dampening their presence in the region.
Concentrated demand in urban areas enables after-school program providers to serve a higher number of children per establishment, dampening their presence in the region.
Concentrated demand in urban areas enables after-school program providers to serve a higher number of children per establishment, dampening their presence in the region.

regulations_points.regulation_description: In order to qualify for any federal funding, including the CCLC program, after-school programs need to meet specific requirements. These often require after-school programs to offer opportunities for physical exercise, academic assistance and snacks, as well as keep detailed spending records. Faith-based schools and after-school program providers are eligible to apply but are subject to additional regulations.

Because after-school programs provide childcare, the industry is subject to heightened regulation to ensure the safety of every child. This means each employee will need to undergo a background check, and programs have an upper limit to how many kids they can care for at a given time based on how many staff are present.

After-school programs need to be licensed by the appropriate state agency. Licensing is typically dependent on staff qualifications, program quality and safety, and facilities are often reviewed to ensure all requirements are being met. Programs providing transportation are subject to additional regulations.

barriers_points.barrier_description: New after-school program providers need to comply with child safety laws and licensing requirements. Those seeking federal funding are subject to heightened requirements and oversight.
It's relatively inexpensive to open an after-school program, as most rent out facilities or locate within schools. Very few materials are required.

After-school programs can gain a competitive edge by providing supplemental education services, opportunities for physical exercise and snacks, but location will still be the determining factor for most parents.

Running an after-school program is very labor-intensive, as regulations limit the maximum child-to-caretaker ratio. Wage expenses regularly make up over half the industry's revenue, making labor costs the most significant barrier to entry.

basis_points.basis_description: Competition is low in many markets since parents simply send their children to whichever after-school program is located in or nearest to their child's school.

After-school program providers are consumer-facing, so they're sensitive to changes in consumer spending and disposable income. After-school programs need to offer competitive rates to avoid forcing parents to rely on friends, family or neighbors.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Parents often don't choose after-school programs and instead use whichever program their child's school chooses to use. This means after-school programs are distributed closely in line with population trends, so there is no exceptionally dominant region for after-school programs.

Because barriers to entry are low, opening an after-school program is inexpensive. New entrants often join the industry and push down concentration. The intense fragmentation of the industry and dominance of small programs make consolidation exceedingly rare, especially as many providers are nonprofit organizations.
Competition is low, so after-school program providers have little to gain by acquiring another program.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Part-Time Workers are Helping Providers Mitigate Wages
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: After-school program providers have dampened wages' effect on profit by upping their reliance on more affordable workers. Providers don't need to provide benefits for part-time caretakers, and inflation's strain on consumers' budgets encouraged many to seek an additional part-time job. Workforces are expanding as after-school program providers bring on additional talent.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: After-School Programs Need Solid Insurance Policies
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Other costs vary among after-school providers, as some offer more services than others. Some programs must pay for transportation and professional development courses for volunteers and staff. This segment also includes insurance-related costs, which are exceptionally important for after-school programs as they work with kids. Insurers often charge higher premiums for after-school program providers.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Running an after-school program is very labor-intensive, as regulations limit the maximum child-to-caretaker ratio. Wage expenses regularly make up over half the industry's revenue, making labor costs the most significant barrier to entry.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The necessity of the industry stabilizes revenue
volatility_points.volatility_description: Parents who rely on after-school programs to take care of their kids while they're otherwise occupied are generally reliable customers. This has changed through COVID-19, though, as work-from-home policies have given consumers the flexibility to pick up their children after school and save money on after-school care.

There are over 120 federal programs that provide assistance to after-school programs. Public funding is usually done on a several-year basis, so eligible after-school programs can better plan year-to-year cost structures. Federal and state support programs can lose funding as government compositions change and new policies become law, which stretches volatility out over multiple years.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Spending power changes can cause year-to-year fluctuations
volatility_points.volatility_description: Still, there is an element of volatility the industry is exposed to as year-to-year shifts in disposable income, consumer spending and consumer confidence can translate to lowered or heightened revenue. These variables were uncharacteristically volatile throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, but government support helped minimize revenue fluctuations.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: After-school programs are now using computer software that tracks enrollment schedules, medical and immunization information, automated invoicing, mobile registration, staffing and other administrative items. After-school care providers also adjust their programs in accordance with the latest research and child-rearing trends, though older methods continue to persist as new ones become popular.

FAQs.question: How does your company target key potential markets?
FAQs.answer: Key markets for the industry are school-age kids, primarily elementary school students, followed by middle schoolers and then high schoolers.

FAQs.question: How do you make sure your prices are attractive to customers?
FAQs.answer: Since most industry revenue comes from tuition fees paid by families, industry revenue relies on families with sufficient disposable income, so after-school program providers must ensure that the price they charge is feasible for families.

FAQs.question: How does your company manage operating expenses to ensure maximum profitability?
FAQs.answer: Profit is low for after-school program providers and is primarily determined by an organization's labor, rent and utilities costs.

FAQs.question: Is your company keeping up-to-date with the latest technology?
FAQs.answer: Since this industry's primary service doesn't need the use of technology, it's largely unaffected by technological changes. While most don't, some after-school care services may compete based on their ability to provide children with learning opportunities using the latest technology.

FAQs.question: What are the primary regulations affecting your organization?
FAQs.answer: After-school care program providers must be licensed according to state licensing requirements. However, after-school programs operating in and staffed by public and private schools are exempt.

FAQs.question: How does your company monitor changes to your regulatory environment?
FAQs.answer: After-school program providers must primarily monitor changes at the state level since most industry regulations are made by states and not by the federal government.

FAQs.question: Has your company sought financing options for low-income individuals and/or families?
FAQs.answer: Demand for afterschool programs is highest among low-income families with busy parents.

FAQs.question: What ongoing financing challenges does your company face?
FAQs.answer: The largest financial costs of operating a program are wages, rent and utility costs.

FAQs.question: What accreditation does your company have? How can you gain standardized recommendations or otherwise improve your program's profile?
FAQs.answer: Accreditation promotes the program to parents and potential employees and can improve occupancy rates.

FAQs.question: Do you offer a diverse range of services? Do you cater to any specific age range with the services you offer?
FAQs.answer: After-school programs with flexible hours can cater to the varied needs of working parents and will be more appealing.

FAQs.question: Do you continually align capacity to demand? What improvements can you implement to improve overall efficiency?
FAQs.answer: To optimize profit, after-school program providers must be able to maintain high occupancy rates.

FAQs.question: Does your organization rely on federal funding from 21st CCLC? What other sources of government funding does your organization receive?
FAQs.answer: Government funding for primary and secondary education. An increase in federal funding allocated for education initiatives increases funding for the large number of government programs that may allocate grant money toward after-school programs.

FAQs.question: How do you reach out to more parents? Are your services focused on a particular age range?
FAQs.answer: An uptick in the number of K-12 students, particularly alongside an increase in the number of two-parent working households, contributes to increased demand for after-school programs.

FAQs.question: Do you notice changes in demand when the unemployment rate changes? If so, do you monitor the unemployment rate and how?
FAQs.answer: When unemployment rises, parents are more likely to care for kids outside of school hours instead of enrolling them in after-school programs.
